name: Tartrazine
description: Artificial yellow dye (Azo). Linked to hyperactivity in children, allergic reactions, and asthma.

name: Sunset Yellow FCF
description: Synthetic orange-yellow dye (Azo). Associated with allergies, hyperactivity, and urticaria.

name: Carmoisine
description: Synthetic red dye (Azo). Banned in several countries; linked to hyperactivity and allergic reactions.

name: Ponceau 4R
description: Synthetic red dye (Azo). Suspected carcinogen; banned in USA and Norway. Linked to hyperactivity.

name: Erythrosine
description: Cherry-pink synthetic dye. Linked to thyroid tumors in animal studies. Phototoxic.

name: Allura Red AC
description: Synthetic red dye (Azo). Associated with hyperactivity in children and allergic reactions.

name: Indigotine
description: Synthetic blue dye. May cause nausea and hypertension in sensitive individuals.

name: Brilliant Blue FCF
description: Synthetic blue dye. Generally considered safe but may cause allergic reactions in aspirin-sensitive people.

name: Fast Green FCF
description: Synthetic green dye. Potential allergen; linked to bladder tumors in animal studies.

name: Caramel Colour (Plain)
description: Natural colour from heated sugar. Generally safe in moderate quantities.

name: Caramel Colour (Sulphite Ammonia)
description: Contains 4-MEI, a potentially carcinogenic byproduct. Common in colas and soy sauce.

name: Annatto
description: Natural orange-red dye from achiote seeds. Generally safe.

name: Titanium Dioxide
description: White pigment. Banned as food additive in EU (2022). Potential genotoxicity from nanoparticles.

name: Sorbic Acid
description: Naturally occurring preservative. Generally considered safe in food amounts.

name: Potassium Sorbate
description: Common preservative. Generally safe but may cause mild skin allergies in some individuals.

name: Benzoic Acid
description: Preservative that can form benzene when combined with ascorbic acid (Vitamin C).

name: Sodium Benzoate
description: Common preservative. Can form benzene (carcinogen) when combined with Vitamin C (ascorbic acid).

name: Sulphur Dioxide
description: Potent preservative. Triggers asthma attacks, headaches, and allergic reactions. Destroys Vitamin B1.

name: Sodium Metabisulphite
description: Sulphite preservative. Can trigger severe asthma, breathing difficulties, and anaphylaxis.

name: Potassium Nitrite
description: Used in cured meats. Can form carcinogenic nitrosamines. IARC Group 2A carcinogen.

name: Sodium Nitrite
description: Curing agent in processed meats. Forms carcinogenic nitrosamines. IARC Group 2A carcinogen.

name: Sodium Nitrate
description: Converts to nitrite in the body. Found in processed meats. Linked to colorectal cancer risk.

name: Calcium Propionate
description: Mold inhibitor used in breads. Linked to irritability and sleep disturbance in children.

name: Ascorbic Acid (Vitamin C)
description: Vitamin C used as antioxidant. Safe, but can form benzene when combined with benzoates.

name: TBHQ (Tertiary Butylhydroquinone)
description: Synthetic antioxidant to prevent rancidity. Linked to immune system damage, nausea, and vision problems.

name: BHA (Butylated Hydroxyanisole)
description: Synthetic antioxidant. IARC classifies as 'possibly carcinogenic to humans' (Group 2B). Endocrine disruptor.

name: BHT (Butylated Hydroxytoluene)
description: Synthetic antioxidant. Linked to liver and kidney damage in high doses. Potential endocrine disruptor.

name: Lecithin
description: Naturally occurring emulsifier from soy or sunflower. Generally safe.

name: Citric Acid
description: Common organic acid found in citrus fruits. Generally safe.

name: Phosphoric Acid
description: Used extensively in colas. Linked to reduced bone density, kidney problems, and calcium depletion.

name: Sodium Phosphate
description: Common in processed foods. Excessive intake linked to cardiovascular risk and kidney damage.

name: Calcium Phosphate
description: Anti-caking agent and mineral supplement. Generally safe in food amounts.

name: Carrageenan
description: Seaweed-derived thickener. Linked to gut inflammation and digestive issues. Under FSSAI review.

name: Guar Gum
description: Naturally derived thickener from guar beans. Generally safe. Common in Indian products.

name: Gum Arabic
description: Natural gum from Acacia tree. Generally safe as thickener and stabilizer.

name: Xanthan Gum
description: Natural polysaccharide used as thickener. Generally safe.

name: Sorbitol
description: Sugar alcohol. Excessive consumption causes bloating, diarrhea, and GI distress.

name: Glycerol
description: Naturally occurring humectant. Generally safe in food use.

name: Polysorbate 80
description: Synthetic emulsifier. May disrupt gut microbiome and promote intestinal inflammation.

name: Polysorbate 60
description: Synthetic emulsifier. Similar concerns to Polysorbate 80 regarding gut health.

name: Pectin
description: Natural gelling agent from fruit. Generally safe and may have prebiotic benefits.

name: Sodium Pyrophosphate
description: Phosphate-based additive. High phosphate intake linked to cardiovascular and renal risk.

name: Sodium Polyphosphate
description: Synthetic phosphate emulsifier. Excessive phosphate intake linked to bone and kidney issues.

name: Sodium CMC (Carboxymethyl Cellulose)
description: Semi-synthetic thickener. Studies suggest it may promote gut inflammation and disrupt microbiome.

name: Mono- and Diglycerides
description: May contain trans-fats. Source can be animal or vegetable fat (non-vegetarian risk).

name: Sodium Stearoyl Lactylate
description: Dough strengthener. Generally considered safe. May be sourced from animal fats.

name: Sodium Bicarbonate
description: Baking soda. Generally safe in food amounts.

name: Potassium Chloride
description: Salt substitute. Can cause hyperkalemia in people with kidney disease.

name: Silicon Dioxide
description: Common anti-caking agent. Nano-sized particles under safety review globally.

name: MSG (Monosodium Glutamate)
description: Common flavour enhancer. Linked to 'Chinese Restaurant Syndrome', headaches, and neurotoxicity in sensitive individuals.

name: Disodium Guanylate
description: Often used with MSG. Should be avoided by people with gout or uric acid issues.

name: Disodium Inosinate
description: Often paired with MSG. Should be avoided by people with gout or uric acid issues.

name: Disodium 5'-Ribonucleotides
description: Blend of INS 627 and INS 631. Avoid with gout. Often used alongside MSG.

name: Dimethylpolysiloxane
description: Silicone-based anti-foaming agent (used in McDonald's frying oil). Controversial safety profile.

name: L-Cysteine
description: Dough improver, often derived from human hair or duck feathers. Non-vegetarian source concern.

name: Acesulfame Potassium (Ace-K)
description: Artificial sweetener 200x sweeter than sugar. Linked to gut microbiome disruption and insulin response alteration.

name: Aspartame
description: Artificial sweetener. IARC classified as 'possibly carcinogenic' (Group 2B, 2023). Breaks down to methanol.

name: Sodium Cyclamate
description: Artificial sweetener banned in USA. Linked to bladder cancer in animal studies.

name: Saccharin
description: Oldest artificial sweetener. Previously linked to cancer; now considered safer but still controversial.

name: Sucralose
description: Chlorinated sugar derivative. May affect gut bacteria and glucose metabolism when heated.

name: Steviol Glycosides (Stevia)
description: Natural zero-calorie sweetener from Stevia plant. Generally considered safe.

name: Neotame
description: Synthetic sweetener 7000-13000x sweeter than sugar. Derived from aspartame. Limited long-term studies.

name: Malic Acid
description: Naturally found in apples. Generally safe as food acidulant.

name: Lactic Acid
description: Naturally occurring acid. Used as preservative and flavouring agent. Generally safe.

name: Acetic Acid
description: Vinegar acid. Naturally occurring. Generally safe.

name: Potassium Carbonate
description: Alkaline salt used in food processing. Generally safe.

name: Tartaric Acid
description: Naturally found in grapes and tamarind. Common in Indian cuisine. Generally safe.

name: Palm Oil
description: High in saturated fat (palmitic acid). Linked to cardiovascular disease. Environmentally controversial.

name: Partially Hydrogenated Vegetable Oil
description: Primary source of artificial trans-fats. FSSAI limits trans-fat to 2%. Linked to heart disease, stroke, and diabetes.

name: Interesterified Fat
description: Trans-fat alternative but may affect glucose metabolism and HDL cholesterol. Under study.

name: Vanaspati (Hydrogenated Fat)
description: Hydrogenated vegetable fat (Indian dalda). Contains trans-fats. FSSAI mandates < 2% trans-fat.

name: Potassium Bromate
description: BANNED by FSSAI in 2016. Known carcinogen. Previously used as bread improver. Still found in some bakery products.

name: Potassium Iodate
description: BANNED by FSSAI in 2016 as flour improver. Can cause thyroid dysfunction in excess.

name: Brominated Vegetable Oil
description: Used in citrus-flavoured drinks. Banned in EU, Japan, India. Linked to bromine toxicity and memory loss.

name: Red 2G
description: Synthetic red dye. BANNED in multiple countries including India. Suspected carcinogen and mutagen.

name: Brown FK
description: Banned food dye. Only legally used in UK for kippers. Banned in most countries.

name: Chlorine
description: Used for bleaching flour. Destroys nutrients and creates harmful byproducts. Banned in EU.

name: Azodicarbonamide (ADA)
description: Dough conditioner/bleaching agent. Banned in EU, Australia. Decomposes to semicarbazide (possible carcinogen).

name: Calcium Disodium EDTA
description: Chelating agent. May deplete essential minerals. High doses affect kidneys.

name: Carnauba Wax
description: Natural plant wax. Used as coating on candies and tablets. Generally safe.

name: Shellac
description: Insect-derived coating (lac beetle). Not suitable for vegans/vegetarians.

name: Curcumin (Turmeric)
description: Natural yellow colour from turmeric. Anti-inflammatory properties. Safe and beneficial.

name: Chlorophyll
description: Natural green pigment from plants. Generally safe.

name: Beta-Carotene
description: Natural orange pigment and Vitamin A precursor. Safe and nutritionally beneficial.

name: High Fructose Corn Syrup (HFCS)
description: Processed sweetener linked to obesity, fatty liver disease, insulin resistance, and metabolic syndrome.

name: Propylene Glycol
description: Moisture retainer also used in antifreeze. FDA GRAS but may cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals.
